text: I am an ECE undergrad wanting to take up Statistical ML in Julia.

elements.text: I am an ECE undergrad wanting to take up Statistical ML in Julia.

text:
Hello Ria. Welcome.  Here are some links to help you get comfortable with Julia at first and then to bring Julia into your pursuit of Statistical Machine Learning.

The Julia Community has gathered some of the best learning resources <https://julialang.org/learning/tutorials/|here>.

For questions about Julia generally, there are three very active, reliable resources:

Slack -- the channel <#C6A044SQH|helpdesk> for general questions about working with Julia, and the channels <#C6821M4KE|statistics> <#C690QRAA3|machine-learning> for more domain specific questions. The posts on Slack are temporary.  To search previously answered questions, use Discourse or  <https://julialang.zulipchat.com/|Zulip> (like Slack uses channels, Zulip uses streams -- you should join some by clicking on the eight rayed circle next to the magnifying glass.  `helpdesk-published`, `statistics` `machine-learning` are appropriate, as will be others.

 <https://discourse.julialang.org/|Discourse> gets the broadest cross-section of The Julia Community involved.  You do not need to join channels or streams. Just visit, search your questions, ask for answers. To ask a question select "Usage" and "First Steps" (if that is appropriate) where it says "all categories" and "all tags" in the upper left, where "New Topic" is at the right (click that to post a question).  If you choose "Domains" (in "all categories"), you will see the domains available for more technical, or more specialized responses.  Always select one of them (under "all tags") before asking your question -- that way the people best able to help will see the posting.

<https://sciml.ai/|SciML> (Scientific Machine Learning) makes well regarded, state-of-the-art software.
There is a github group, <https://juliastats.org/|JuliaStats> may be of interest for reference or participation.
There is a book, <https://statisticswithjulia.org/index.html|Statistics with Julia>, now in <https://statisticswithjulia.org/StatisticsWithJuliaDRAFT.pdf|draft form> with sections you may enjoy.
